reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s percentile-based definition/normalisation of “best feasible future” (99.99th percentile set to 1) and the resulting 0.5/0.9 cutoffs for “mostly-great”/“near-best.” This is moderately central because the paper uses those thresholds to frame how “hard” eutopia is and to motivate intuitions like common-sense utopia falling far below 0.5; if the scaling is artifactually stretched by extreme tail scenarios, the headline ‘mostly-great is rare’ could be partly definitional. However, much of the essay’s case for fussiness also comes from substantive claims (many independent moral dimensions, population ethics/digital minds issues, bounded vs unbounded value-function arguments), which would still support a narrow-target story even under different anchors, so the position wouldn’t fully collapse. Strength is moderate: the objection is conceptually coherent and identifies a real sensitivity, but it doesn’t show that the 99.99th percentile is in fact typically “poisoned” by a single exotic construction, nor that alternative reasonable anchoring schemes would materially reverse the rarity/fussiness conclusions; the authors also explicitly intend a ‘best feasible’ (not absolute maximum) anchor, which partially defuses the ‘tautology’ charge. Relevance is high because it engages a methodological choice internal to Forethought’s Better Futures framework (how to operationalise ‘best feasible’/value loss), rather than disputing Tier-1 premises, and would help refine their quantitative framing if developed further. Overall impact is therefore limited but nontrivial.
title: "Percentile Poisoning" undermines the 99.99th-percentile value scale
